section.intro.title: AVAILABILITY, PERMITS AND ACCESS TO CHACHABAMBA (SHORT INCA TRAIL)
section.intro.p1: Access to Chachabamba is limited and requires Short Inca Trail permits. Use this page to check availability and plan your visit in advance.
section.location.title: Where is Chachabamba?
section.location.p1: Chachabamba is located at km 104 of the railway between Cusco and Machu Picchu, in the province of Urubamba, Cusco region, Peru. It is one of the main gateways to the Short Inca Trail (2 days), a strategic ceremonial point before reaching Machu Picchu.
section.location.list: Access: On foot only via the Short Inca Trail, after a train ride to km 104.
section.see.title: What can you see in Chachabamba?

section.availability.title: AVAILABILITY TO VISIT CHACHABAMBA
section.availability.p1: Visiting Chachabamba depends entirely on Inca Trail permit availability, especially the Short Inca Trail (2 days and 1 night). Access is regulated by the Ministry of Culture and allows a maximum of 250 visitors per day (including guides and porters). That is why booking in advance is key.
section.recommendations.title: RECOMMENDATIONS
section.recommendations.pack.title: What to bring to visit Chachabamba?
section.recommendations.pack.p1: Although the Short Inca Trail is not as long as the classic 4‑day trek, it requires preparation. Pack light but functional gear because the weather can vary between strong sun, unexpected rain, and temperature changes.
section.recommendations.pack.list: Inca Trail and Machu Picchu tickets printed or digital.
Waterproof trekking boots with good traction.
Sunscreen, sunglasses, and a hat for the Andean sun.
Insect repellent, especially in jungle areas.
Energy snacks like nuts, bars, or chocolate.
20–30 L backpack with a waist belt.
section.recommendations.pack.tip: Expert tip: avoid overloading your backpack. Bring only essentials and coordinate with your agency on what is included (food, water, oxygen, etc.).
section.recommendations.tips.title: Tips for visiting Chachabamba
section.recommendations.tips.list: Acclimatize in Cusco or the Sacred Valley at least 2 days before.
Bring cash in soles; there are no ATMs or card terminals on the route.
Avoid alcohol and heavy meals the night before, and sleep well.
Verify your agency is certified and uses professional guides.
Make sure you are physically prepared for 6–7 hours of hiking.
section.recommendations.alert.title: Very important recommendation:
section.recommendations.alert.p1: Chachabamba has limited spots and high demand. If you plan to do the Short Inca Trail, book your permits months in advance, especially during high season. Don’t leave it to the last minute.
